Wow, its rare that you see someone blatantly disregard logic 
unapologetically as you have in your rebuttal to Bill Gates.  First, it 
might be that the "law broke the law".. I'll give you that.  However, 
Edward Snowden's mechanism for exposing that was also illegal.  So, 
assuming you're right, then BOTH parties broke the law.  Snowden did not 
only expose the fact that illegal surveillance was taking place, which 
could have been done in any number of ways, but he also freely released 
TONS of legally acquired data.  Snowden completely circumvented the law in 
what he did.  Bad behavior does not justify more bad behavior.  

A more appropriate approach would have been for him to put his evidence on 
a thumb drive, leave work, and walk into the nearest prosecutors office or 
police station.  That would have shown clear intent to reform the system, 
rather than punish or defeat it, and would have at least won him far far 
far more popular support, which would have also certainly gained him a 
pardon for any of the laws he broke while exposing the data to the 
prosecutors office.

Laws exist for a reason.. 

Another way to look at it:  Suppose that you come home and someone is 
loading your TV into their car, and you're holding a gun.  You can see 
their tag, can clearly make out their face, and so on.  Shooting that 
person would almost certainly end the whole problem.  However, you have 
other options, such as calling the police, firing a warning shot, etc, etc. 
 The law does not allow you to shoot them... and if you do, you will be 
punished for it.  All parties must act within the confines of the law, 
regardless of what others are doing.﻿

1:26 It's a red herring. I never thought I'd hear Gates use a logical 
fallacy, but then I haven't really seen the context. Sometimes in real time 
we [humans] speak quickly, such to the extent of reflexive vernacular.

That's my guess, anyway -- concerning Bill's comment about breaking the law 
and what constitutes a hero. Even though Bill would clearly know this, I'll 
go ahead and elaborate. I say it's a red herring because, to qualify as a 
hero, it does not necessarily intersect legal matters. You can prove this 
to yourself with a venn diagram. Suppose you have two circles. There is a 
circle for heroes and a circle for people who have broken laws. It's only 
reasonable to expect these sets to overlap. 

Nevertheless, calling someone a hero is largely subject to interpretation. 
Consequently, this is another issue which complicates things. Law is 
(usually) thoroughly documented. There is little room to fashion poetic 
hyperbole. Granted, we're oversimplifying, because laws can be interpreted 
to a certain degree. You're bound to find gray areas here and there. What 
you should take away, however, is to note the differences between these 
data sets. Once you figure this out, then you'll be a hero. ﻿
